user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of free_unmarked:
```c
static void
free_unmarked (struct MHD_PostProcessor *pp)
{
  if ( (NULL != pp->content_name) &&
       (0 == (pp->have & NE_content_name)) )
  {
    free (pp->content_name);
    pp->content_name = NULL;
  }
  if ( (NULL != pp->content_type) &&
       (0 == (pp->have & NE_content_type)) )
  {
    free (pp->content_type);
    pp->content_type = NULL;
  }
  if ( (NULL != pp->content_filename) &&
       (0 == (pp->have & NE_content_filename)) )
  {
    free (pp->content_filename);
    pp->content_filename = NULL;
  }
  if ( (NULL != pp->content_transfer_encoding) &&
       (0 == (pp->have & NE_content_transfer_encoding)) )
  {
    free (pp->content_transfer_encoding);
    pp->content_transfer_encoding = NULL;
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
    free (pp->content_filename);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the presented code. The call free(pp->content_filename) invokes the standard library function free, not free_unmarked, so free_unmarked does not call itself directly or indirectly. (A hypothetical violation scenario would be if free were redefined to call free_unmarked — for example via a macro like #define free free_unmarked or an implementation hook where free() ultimately calls free_unmarked — which would make free_unmarked indirectly call itself and thus violate Rule 17.2.)
